DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Cancer Margin Distance Centimeter Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value for the distance of invasive carcinoma from the nearest margin.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the distance between an invasive cancer and the surgical margin, the edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.:The space between two objects or points.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
The space separating two objects or points.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Number of centimeters, expressed as a value with 2 decimals and total of 6 digits.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
